ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Grammatical rules of classical arabic as well as its forms
Reading and translating classical Arabic literature (Quran, historic tales, etc); parsing verbs in all forms and translating in context; grammar rules
Ability to read actual texts in classical Arabic (we focused on histories). Continuation of grammar and vocab.
I learned the grammar of Classical Arabic, especially derived stems, as well as how to use dictionaries and other resources to read actual texts!

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: High level of engagement, great book
Weaknesses: Don't engage in Arabic conversations as much as I'd like to

Strength: typically small class size so you can really learn at your preferred pace
Weaknesses: only useful for improving reading skills of classical texts; horrible textbook

Instead of following Thackston's textbook, we pivoted to reading actual texts after spring break. Challenging but highly rewarding--still, some further focus on certain grammatical points from the book would have been helpful.

I think the course got me much farther in Arabic than I thought I could get because of its flexible design. The shift from Thackston to al-Tabari felt a bit abrupt but I dont think theres another way to learn a language.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, especially if they want to know the grammatical foundations of Arabic

If the student is interested in learning how to read Classical Arabic texts but not if they are looking to improve their general knowledge of the Arabic language or are interested in reading modern text
If you would like to be able to read classical Arabic texts, then of course.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to eventually read texts in Classical Arabic! It helps you develop the necessary skills and Arabic is a very beautiful language.
